Description: Limestone relief of Amenmose: divided into two scenes carved in sunk relief with incised texts. On the left the charioteer Amenmose and his son, the scribe Mehu, adore Osiris and the four sons of Horus who stand in mummiform guise on a lotus blossom in front of Osiris. On the right side of the relief the scribe of the treasury Mahu, and his mother, the chantress of Amun Ḥwt.ḥr, adore the god Anubis who stands behind an altar on which rests a water-pot cooled by a lotus blossom.
Curator's comments: Amenmose can be identified with the charioteer of the lord of the two lands, Amenmose, who appears together with his wife, the chantress of Horus the Behdetite Hathor, on the stela of their son, the scribe of the treasury of the temple of Ramses-meryamun in the estate of Re‘ Mahu, now in the Turin Museum (J. Ruffle, 'Glimpses of Ancient Egypt' (Warminster, 1979), 56,63 pl. Ill). The appearance of the steward of the Ramesseum Yupa on the Turin stela dates it to the reign of Ramses II. Bibliography: H. Frankfort, 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 14 (1928), 243, No. 13, pl. 23:3; B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' V (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 65; K. A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside inscriptions : translated & annotated Translations Vol.3, Ramesses II, his contemporaries' (Oxford, 2000), 248-9;
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.20-21)
Exhibition history: 2022-2023 7 Oct-26 Feb, Middlesbrough, Dorman Museum, NP Ancient Egyptians
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Sons of Horus
